item.description: Authors: OTI Published: May 2018 URL: https://www.newamerica.org/oti/press-releases/breaking-fbi-admits-its-claims-going-dark-were-overblown-based-bad-math/ Abstract: The Washington Post reported that the FBI has been overstating the number of encrypted mobile devices that it could not unlock in 2017.

item.title: Debate: Law Enforcement vs. Smartphone Encryption
item.description: Authors: New America Published: November 2014 URL: https://www.newamerica.org/oti/events/debate-on-law-enforcement-vs-smartphone-encryption/ Abstract: The recent decision by Apple and Google to enable encryption by default on new iPhones and Android smartphones, so that only the user can unlock his or her phone, has led to strong complaints from law enforcement agencies arguing that the move will deprive them of critical evidence. The Attorney General and the FBI Director have gone so far as to suggest that Congress may need to step in and tell companies to redesign their products, to ensure that government investigators can access encrypted data or wiretap online communications when they have appropriate legal authority like a search warrant.

item.title: Surveillance Costs\_ The NSA's Impact on the Economy, Internet Freedom \& Cybersecurity
item.description: Authors: Robyn Greene, Danielle Kehl, Robert Morgus, and Kevin Bankston Published: July 2014 URL: https://www.newamerica.org/oti/policy-papers/surveillance-costs-the-nsas-impact-on-the-economy-internet-freedom-cybersecurity/ Abstract: It has been over a year since The Guardian reported the first story on the National Security Agency’s surveillance programs based on the leaks from former NSA contractor Edward Snowden, yet the national conversation remains largely mired in a simplistic debate over the tradeoffs between national security and individual privacy. It is time to start weighing the overall costs and benefits more broadly.
